articles.title: Is Cloud Seeding Helping Ski Resorts Produce More Snow?
articles.description: While there are ski resorts believe cloud seeding help produce more powder, the critics of the practice are growing.
articles.content: As the West deals with a very underwhelming winter (minus this week), some are wondering what ways there are to get out of it. In theory, one solution is cloud seeding, but its effectiveness is debatable. Bloomberg News reported last week that various states and ski resorts are using cloud seeding to increase snowfall totals from snowstorms. Colorado and Utah are currently leading the way, but the results aren’t definitive enough to solve the West’s drought. There are a few methods that are used for cloud seeding. Near Winter Park Resort, a machine places silver iodide into the arm. When storms approach, they can increase precipitation. Alternatively, on cloudy days with no expected precipitation, it can produce snow. This operation is run by DRI, a non-profit research firm. Winter Park estimates that it helped produce 24 inches of snow in 2024. articles.description: According to PeakRankings, Castle Mountain is one of the most slept on ski areas in Alberta, overshadowed by the larger Banff area resorts.
articles.content: Alberta is home to several popular ski resorts like Lake Louise , Banff Sunshine , and Mt. Norquay , and more, but there are a few ski areas that go rather unnoticed despite their high quality terrain and conditions. According to PeakRankings, Castle Mountain is one of those underrated resorts, often overshadowed by the more famous resorts in the area. Castle stands out for its light and dry snow accumulation. Wind-drifted snow provides fresh tracks even longer than its snowfall totals might expect, alongside some of the most incredible steep skiing and riding in Canada and a competitive vertical drop. articles.title: Utah Ski Resort Temporarily Closes Amid Underwhelming Winter
articles.description: In the latest sign of Utah's bleak winter, one ski resort has announced its temporarily shut down its lifts.
articles.content: Eden, Utah — It’s been the worst winter ever for Utah’s ski industry in terms of snowpack, so it’s not surprising that one ski resort has had to temporarily pause operations. Yesterday, Nordic Valley announced that it is pausing operations for the 2025-26 season. While they expect to reopen soon, it’s expected to be out of action for the next several days, which means they’re missing out on President’s Day Weekend. Luckily, snow is predicted early next week, which should help them out. View this post on Instagram The announcement comes as it’s been a weird past couple of seasons for Nordic Valley. The early 2020s saw a massive expansion for the ski resort, with the opening of the Nordic Express six-pack chairlift. The 2023-24 season was without the Apollo chairlift, which is the easiest way to reach the new lift. It also saw a fire that destroyed the base lodge. articles.content: It was, as they say, a game of two halves So often PlanetSKI is told that there’s much more to winter in the mountains, and so often we’re not fully convinced. THE SKIING Grindelwald has one of the most dramatic settings in Europe, gazing up at the mighty north face of the Eiger and its surrounding peaks. It’s part of the Jungfrau Ski Region that encompasses two valleys and three resorts, with more than 200km of runs. articles.content: TL;DR – Read This First The 2025–26 winter season has seen unusually unstable snowpacks across both the Alps and North America. Despite repeated avalanche warnings from ski patrols, mountain guides and rescue services, many skiers and snowboarders continue to go off-piste during high-risk periods — sometimes ignoring advice, challenging warnings, or reacting aggressively when asked to turn back. When accidents happen, the same professionals who tried to prevent these decisions are forced to carry out complex and dangerous rescue operations , often in extremely unstable terrain. articles.content: Val Thorens winter driving rules have been tightened in the Belleville Valley, covering Val Thorens, Les Menuires and Saint-Martin-de-Belleville. These Val Thorens winter driving measures apply throughout the entire ski season. A new municipal decree confirms that vehicles must be equipped with either four winter tyres in good condition or snow chains . Snow socks and all-season tyres are explicitly not considered adequate equipment. For a full breakdown of winter tyre and snow chain rules across the Alps and Europe — including what’s accepted where and why — see our guide to winter tyres and snow chains . These Val Thorens winter driving rules are enforced throughout the Belleville Valley ski season. Under Article 4.2 of the decree, law enforcement may deny access to the resorts if vehicles are fitted with snow socks that are not suitable for heavily snow-covered or icy roads.
